epignathus	Epignathus is a teratoma originating from the upper jaw, usually connected with the sphenoid bone or hard palate. [PMID:19240824, UToronto:chum]
brachmann de lange syndrome	A syndrome characterized by growth retardation, severe MENTAL RETARDATION, short stature, a low-pitched growling cry, brachycephaly, low-set ears, webbed neck, carp mouth, depressed nasal bridge, bushy eyebrows meeting at the midline, hirsutism, and malformations of the hands. The condition may occur sporadically or be associated with an autosomal dominant pattern of inheritance or duplication of the long arm of chromosome 3. (Menkes, Textbook of Child Neurology, 5th ed, p231)
dicentric chromosome	An abnormal chromosome with two centromeres as opposed to the normal one centromere.
laurence moon bardet biedl syndrome	En autosomal, recessiv störning kännetecknad av retinitis pigmentosa, polydaktyli, övervikt, psykisk funktionsnedsättning, hypogenitalism, njurdysplasi och kortvuxenhet. Syndromet skiljer sig från Laurence-Moons syndrom.
papillon-léage and psaume syndrome	An X-linked inherited syndrome caused by mutations in the OFD1 gene mapped to chromosome Xp22.2. It is characterized by malformations of the face, oral cavity, and fingers.
balanced translocation of chromosome	Interchanges of genetic material among different chromosomes following the breaking off of pieces of chromosomes such that the total chromosome composition may still contain all of the genetic material.Balanced Chromosomal Rearrangement.
alport syndrome	hereditary disorder characterized by progressive sensorineural hearing loss, progressive pyelonephritis or glomerulonephritis, and, occasionally, ocular defects; transmitted as an autosomal dominant or X-linked trait.
blood group abo	The major human blood type system which depends on the presence or absence of two antigens A and B. Type O occurs when neither A nor B is present and AB when both are present. A and B are genetic factors that determine the presence of enzymes for the synthesis of certain glycoproteins mainly in the red cell membrane.
blood type ab	A blood group indicating the presence on erythrocytes of both the A and B forms of the H Antigen.
blood group o	A blood group indicating the absence on erythrocytes of both the A and B forms of the H Antigen.
abo blood groups	The major human blood type system which depends on the presence or absence of two antigens A and B. Type O occurs when neither A nor B is present and AB when both are present. A and B are genetic factors that determine the presence of enzymes for the synthesis of certain glycoproteins mainly in the red cell membrane.
blood type a	A blood group indicating the presence on erythrocytes of only the A form of the H Antigen.
abo blood group system	The major human blood type system which depends on the presence or absence of two antigens A and B. Type O occurs when neither A nor B is present and AB when both are present. A and B are genetic factors that determine the presence of enzymes for the synthesis of certain glycoproteins mainly in the red cell membrane.
ab blood type	A blood group indicating the presence on erythrocytes of both the A and B forms of the H Antigen.
blood groups--abo system	The major human blood type system which depends on the presence or absence of two antigens A and B. Type O occurs when neither A nor B is present and AB when both are present. A and B are genetic factors that determine the presence of enzymes for the synthesis of certain glycoproteins mainly in the red cell membrane.
abo groups	The major human blood type system which depends on the presence or absence of two antigens A and B. Type O occurs when neither A nor B is present and AB when both are present. A and B are genetic factors that determine the presence of enzymes for the synthesis of certain glycoproteins mainly in the red cell membrane.
abo typing	The determination of the blood type of an individual by testing for the presence or absence of A antigen and/or B antigen on the surface of red blood cells.
abomasum	The fourth stomach of ruminating animals. It is also called the "true" stomach. It is an elongated pear-shaped sac lying on the floor of the abdomen, on the right-hand side, and roughly between the seventh and twelfth ribs. It leads to the beginning of the small intestine. (From Black's Veterinary Dictionary, 17th ed)
experimental organism anatomical concept	A non-human biological structure, fluid or other substance; excludes single molecular entities.
cdisc send biospecimens terminology	A terminology set that includes concepts relevant to CDISC SEND biospecimens.
ruminant stomachs	A component of the DIGESTIVE SYSTEM of RUMINANTS which consists of the ABOMASUM; OMASUM; RETICULUM; and RUMEN.
abomasum structure	The fourth stomach of ruminating animals. It is also called the "true" stomach. It is an elongated pear-shaped sac lying on the floor of the abdomen, on the right-hand side, and roughly between the seventh and twelfth ribs. It leads to the beginning of the small intestine. (From Black's Veterinary Dictionary, 17th ed)
ruminant stomach	A component of the DIGESTIVE SYSTEM of RUMINANTS which consists of the ABOMASUM; OMASUM; RETICULUM; and RUMEN.
abortus	Foster av ett däggdjur utstött på grund av framkallad abort eller missfall.
fetal structure	The anatomical parts that make up a viviparous mammalian organism in the postembryonic period of development.
embryonic structure	The anatomical parts that make up an organism in the early stages of development.
abortifacients	Chemical substances that interrupt pregnancy after implantation.
mifepristone	A progestational and glucocorticoid hormone antagonist. Its inhibition of progesterone induces bleeding during the luteal phase and in early pregnancy by releasing endogenous prostaglandins from the endometrium or decidua. As a glucocorticoid receptor antagonist, the drug has been used to treat hypercortisolism in patients with nonpituitary CUSHING SYNDROME.
abortient agent	Chemical substances that interrupt pregnancy after implantation.
prostaglandin f	(9 alpha,11 alpha,13E,15S)-9,11,15-Trihydroxyprost-13-en-1-oic acid (PGF(1 alpha)); (5Z,9 alpha,11,alpha,13E,15S)-9,11,15-trihydroxyprosta-5,13-dien-1-oic acid (PGF(2 alpha)); (5Z,9 alpha,11 alpha,13E,15S,17Z)-9,11,15-trihydroxyprosta-5,13,17-trien-1-oic acid (PGF(3 alpha)). A family of prostaglandins that includes three of the six naturally occurring prostaglandins. All naturally occurring PGF have an alpha configuration at the 9-carbon position. They stimulate uterine and bronchial smooth muscle and are often used as oxytocics.
abortifacient agent	Chemical substances that interrupt pregnancy after implantation.
mifepristone product	A progestational and glucocorticoid hormone antagonist. Its inhibition of progesterone induces bleeding during the luteal phase and in early pregnancy by releasing endogenous prostaglandins from the endometrium or decidua. As a glucocorticoid receptor antagonist, the drug has been used to treat hypercortisolism in patients with nonpituitary CUSHING SYNDROME.
non-steroidal abortifacient agents	Non-steroidal chemical compounds with abortifacient activity.
trichosanthin	Plant-derived ribosome-inactivating protein (RIP) purified from the Chinese medicinal herb tian-hua-fen which is obtained from the root tubers of Trichosanthes kirilowii. It has been used as an abortifacient and in the treatment of trophoblastic tumors. GLQ223 (Compound Q), a highly purified form of trichosanthin, has been proposed as antiviral treatment for AIDS.
nonsteroidal abortifacient agents	Non-steroidal chemical compounds with abortifacient activity.
compound q	Plant-derived ribosome-inactivating protein (RIP) purified from the Chinese medicinal herb tian-hua-fen which is obtained from the root tubers of Trichosanthes kirilowii. It has been used as an abortifacient and in the treatment of trophoblastic tumors. GLQ223 (Compound Q), a highly purified form of trichosanthin, has been proposed as antiviral treatment for AIDS.
carboprost	A nonsteroidal abortifacient agent that is effective in both the first and second trimesters of PREGNANCY.
misoprostol	A synthetic analog of natural prostaglandin E1. It produces a dose-related inhibition of gastric acid and pepsin secretion, and enhances mucosal resistance to injury. It is an effective anti-ulcer agent and also has oxytocic properties.
steroid abortifacients	Steroidal compounds with abortifacient activity.
steroidal abortifacient agents	Steroidal compounds with abortifacient activity.
vaginal expulsion of foetus	Expulsion of the product of FERTILIZATION before completing the term of GESTATION and without deliberate interference.
spontaneous abortion	Expulsion of the product of FERTILIZATION before completing the term of GESTATION and without deliberate interference.
dydrogesterone	A synthetic progestational hormone with no androgenic or estrogenic properties. Unlike many other progestational compounds, dydrogesterone produces no increase in temperature and does not inhibit OVULATION.
abortion spontaneous	Expulsion of the product of FERTILIZATION before completing the term of GESTATION and without deliberate interference.
desogestrel	A synthetic progestational hormone used often as the progestogenic component of combined oral contraceptive agents (ORAL CONTRACEPTIVES, COMBINED).

abortion	The unintentional or intentional loss of a pregnancy before 22 weeks gestation.

missed abortions	The retention in the UTERUS of a dead FETUS two months or more after its DEATH.
complete abortion	Expulsion of all the products of conception following spontaneous, medical or operative pregnancy termination.
vanishing twin syndrome	A multiple pregnancy that over time is spontaneously reduced by one or more embryos which are then resorbed.
peri-implantational loss	Pregnancy loss before 5th week of gestation with no gestational sac visible on ultrasonogram.

molar pregnancy	Trophoblastic hyperplasia associated with normal gestation, or molar pregnancy. It is characterized by the swelling of the CHORIONIC VILLI and elevated human CHORIONIC GONADOTROPIN. Hydatidiform moles or molar pregnancy may be categorized as complete or partial based on their gross morphology, histopathology, and karyotype.
hydatidiform mole nos	Trophoblastic hyperplasia associated with normal gestation, or molar pregnancy. It is characterized by the swelling of the CHORIONIC VILLI and elevated human CHORIONIC GONADOTROPIN. Hydatidiform moles or molar pregnancy may be categorized as complete or partial based on their gross morphology, histopathology, and karyotype.
miscarriage of pregnancy	Expulsion of the product of FERTILIZATION before completing the term of GESTATION and without deliberate interference.
anembryonic pregnancy	Pregnancy loss with visible gestational sac or yolk sac or both but no visible embryo on ultrasonogram.
placental hamartoma	Hamartoma-like growth in the placenta consisting of blood vessels. [HPO:sdoelken, PMID:20594143, PMID:24251055]
breus; mole	A large maternal clot that separates the chorionic plate from the villous chorion. [PMID:11125254, UToronto:chum]

abortion miss	The retention in the UTERUS of a dead FETUS two months or more after its DEATH.
progesterone	The major progestational steroid that is secreted primarily by the CORPUS LUTEUM and the PLACENTA. Progesterone acts on the UTERUS, the MAMMARY GLANDS and the BRAIN. It is required in EMBRYO IMPLANTATION; PREGNANCY maintenance, and the development of mammary tissue for MILK production. Progesterone, converted from PREGNENOLONE, also serves as an intermediate in the biosynthesis of GONADAL STEROID HORMONES and adrenal CORTICOSTEROIDS.
foetal disorders	Pathophysiological conditions of the FETUS in the UTERUS. Some fetal diseases may be treated with FETAL THERAPIES.
miss abortion	The retention in the UTERUS of a dead FETUS two months or more after its DEATH.
retention	The condition of remaining in a place or position or of holding within.
fetal dis	Pathophysiological conditions of the FETUS in the UTERUS. Some fetal diseases may be treated with FETAL THERAPIES.
fetal structures	The anatomical parts that make up a viviparous mammalian organism in the postembryonic period of development.
infective abortion	Any type of abortion, induced or spontaneous, that is associated with infection of the UTERUS and its appendages. It is characterized by FEVER, uterine tenderness, and foul discharge.
sepsis	Systemic inflammatory response syndrome with a proven or suspected infectious etiology. When sepsis is associated with organ dysfunction distant from the site of infection, it is called severe sepsis. When sepsis is accompanied by HYPOTENSION despite adequate fluid infusion, it is called SEPTIC SHOCK.
septic abortion	Any type of abortion, induced or spontaneous, that is associated with infection of the UTERUS and its appendages. It is characterized by FEVER, uterine tenderness, and foul discharge.
infectious disorder	An illness caused by an infectious agent or its toxins that occurs through the direct or indirect transmission of the infectious agent or its products from an infected individual or via an animal, vector or the inanimate environment to a susceptible animal or human host.
infective agent	Any organism, such as a virus, parasite, or bacterium, that is capable of invading body tissues and multiplying.
microbials	organism of microscopic or ultramicroscopic size.
abortion; sepsis	Any type of abortion, induced or spontaneous, that is associated with infection of the UTERUS and its appendages. It is characterized by FEVER, uterine tenderness, and foul discharge.
microorganism	Microorganisms, bacteria, fungi and other organisms.
systemic infectious disease	Systemic inflammatory response syndrome with a proven or suspected infectious etiology. When sepsis is associated with organ dysfunction distant from the site of infection, it is called severe sepsis. When sepsis is accompanied by HYPOTENSION despite adequate fluid infusion, it is called SEPTIC SHOCK.
blood	A liquid tissue with the primary function of transporting oxygen and carbon dioxide. It supplies the tissues with nutrients, removes waste products, and contains various components of the immune system defending the body against infection.
infected abortion	Any type of abortion, induced or spontaneous, that is associated with infection of the UTERUS and its appendages. It is characterized by FEVER, uterine tenderness, and foul discharge.
infectious disease	An illness caused by an infectious agent or its toxins that occurs through the direct or indirect transmission of the infectious agent or its products from an infected individual or via an animal, vector or the inanimate environment to a susceptible animal or human host.
abortion septic	Any type of abortion, induced or spontaneous, that is associated with infection of the UTERUS and its appendages. It is characterized by FEVER, uterine tenderness, and foul discharge.
single-celled organism	organism of microscopic or ultramicroscopic size.
therapeutic abortions	Abortion induced to save the life or health of a pregnant woman. (From Dorland, 28th ed)

therapeutics	Procedures concerned with the remedial treatment or prevention of diseases.
therapeutic abortion	Abortion induced to save the life or health of a pregnant woman. (From Dorland, 28th ed)
pregnancy termination counselling	Consulting with a client/patient, who wishes to have an elective abortion, to discuss and/or plan her treatment. Service is billed in 15-minute increments.
abortion ther	Abortion induced to save the life or health of a pregnant woman. (From Dorland, 28th ed)
legal termination of pregnancy	Lawfully induced expulsion of all products of conception.
uterus	The hollow thick-walled muscular organ in the female PELVIS. It consists of the fundus which is the site of EMBRYO IMPLANTATION and FETAL DEVELOPMENT. Beyond the isthmus at the perineal end of fundus, is CERVIX UTERI (the neck) opening into VAGINA. Beyond the isthmi at the upper abdominal end of fundus, are the FALLOPIAN TUBES.
top - termination of pregnancy	Intentional removal of a fetus from the uterus by any of a number of techniques. (POPLINE, 1978)
therapeutic; abortion	Abortion induced to save the life or health of a pregnant woman. (From Dorland, 28th ed)

therapeutic	Relating to or involved in therapy.
ther abortion	Abortion induced to save the life or health of a pregnant woman. (From Dorland, 28th ed)
evacuation	Removal of the contents of a body cavity or container

Beyond the isthmus at the perineal end of fundus, is CERVIX UTERI (the neck) opening into VAGINA. Beyond the isthmi at the upper abdominal end of fundus, are the FALLOPIAN TUBES.
induced; abortion	Abortion brought on intentionally.
threatened abortion	UTERINE BLEEDING from a GESTATION of less than 20 weeks without any CERVICAL DILATATION. It is characterized by vaginal bleeding, lower back discomfort, or midline pelvic cramping and a risk factor for MISCARRIAGE.
ergometrine	An ergot alkaloid (ERGOT ALKALOIDS) with uterine and VASCULAR SMOOTH MUSCLE contractile properties.
threatened; miscarriage	UTERINE BLEEDING from a GESTATION of less than 20 weeks without any CERVICAL DILATATION. It is characterized by vaginal bleeding, lower back discomfort, or midline pelvic cramping and a risk factor for MISCARRIAGE.
phenprocoumon	Coumarin derivative that acts as a long acting oral anticoagulant.
abortion; threatened	UTERINE BLEEDING from a GESTATION of less than 20 weeks without any CERVICAL DILATATION. It is characterized by vaginal bleeding, lower back discomfort, or midline pelvic cramping and a risk factor for MISCARRIAGE.
anisindione	A synthetic indanedione anticoagulant. Anisindione interferes with the vitamin K-dependent hepatic synthesis of active clotting factors by inhibiting the reduction of vitamin K. This leads to an inhibition of gamma-carboxylation of glutamic acid residues to gamma-carboxyglutamic acid in clotting factors II, VII, IX and X. The consequential effects of this inhibition include a reduced activity of these clotting factors and prolonged blood clotting time.
sodium warfarin	The sodium salt form of warfarin, a coumarin and a vitamin K antagonist, with anticoagulant activity. Warfarin sodium inhibits both vitamin K and vitamin K epoxide reductases, thereby interfering with the cyclic interconversion of vitamin K epoxide to its reduced form, vitamin KH2. Vitamin KH2 is a cofactor for the carboxylation of glutamate residues on the N-terminal regions of vitamin K-dependent proteins. As a result, maturation of vitamin K-dependent coagulation factors II, VII, IX, and X and anticoagulant proteins C and S is inhibited. Without these coagulation factors, thrombogenesis and blood clot formation are prevented. Check for "https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/intervention/C1658" active clinical trials using this agent. ("http://ncit.nci.nih.gov/ncitbrowser/ConceptReport.jsp?dictionary=NCI%20Thesaurus&code=C1658" NCI Thesaurus)
pregnancy	The status during which female mammals carry their developing young (EMBRYOS or FETUSES) in utero before birth, beginning from FERTILIZATION to BIRTH.
abortion threatened	UTERINE BLEEDING from a GESTATION of less than 20 weeks without any CERVICAL DILATATION. It is characterized by vaginal bleeding, lower back discomfort, or midline pelvic cramping and a risk factor for MISCARRIAGE.
antepartum hemorrhage	A clinical syndrome that is characterized by bleeding during the second or third trimester of pregnancy. Pathologic etiologies attributable to the pregnant state include placenta previa, morbidly adherent placenta, vasa previa, placental abruption, cesarean scar pregnancy, intra-abdominal pregnancy, and uterine rupture.
antepart hem nos-antepar	A clinical syndrome that is characterized by bleeding during the second or third trimester of pregnancy. Pathologic etiologies attributable to the pregnant state include placenta previa, morbidly adherent placenta, vasa previa, placental abruption, cesarean scar pregnancy, intra-abdominal pregnancy, and uterine rupture.
pregnancy complication	Conditions or pathological processes associated with pregnancy. They can occur during or after pregnancy, and range from minor discomforts to serious diseases that require medical interventions. They include diseases in pregnant females, and pregnancies in females with diseases.
veterinary abortion	Premature expulsion of the FETUS in animals.
abreaction	A process in psychotherapy in which the patient is "desensitized" to emotionally painful, often forgotten (repressed) memories by recalling and reacting to them in the "safety" of the treatment setting.
catharses	The release of ideas, thoughts, and repressed material from the unconscious, accompanied by an emotional response and relief. (From Dorland, 28th ed)
abrin	A toxic lectin from the seeds of jequirity, Abrus precatorius L. Very active poison. Five different proteins have so far been isolated: Abrus agglutinin, the component responsible for: hemagglutinating activity, & abrins a-d, the toxic principals each consisting of two peptide chains are held together by disulfide bonds.
toxin	A substance that is produced by a living organism and is toxic, noxious, or poisonous.
biological toxin	poison, usually protein, produced by higher plants, animals, or microorganisms that is toxic to other living organisms.
abrins	A toxic lectin from the seeds of jequirity, Abrus precatorius L. Very active poison. Five different proteins have so far been isolated: Abrus agglutinin, the component responsible for: hemagglutinating activity, & abrins a-d, the toxic principals each consisting of two peptide chains are held together by disulfide bonds.
chemical challenge agent name response	Terminology related to the names of chemical challenge agents.
abruptio placentae	Premature separation of the normally implanted PLACENTA from the UTERUS. Signs of varying degree of severity include UTERINE BLEEDING, uterine MUSCLE HYPERTONIA, and FETAL DISTRESS or FETAL DEATH.
placental disorders	Pathological processes or abnormal functions of the PLACENTA.

traumatic hemorrhage	Vascular rupture, and the resulting loss of blood, due to physical injury.
placental abruption	Premature separation of the normally implanted PLACENTA from the UTERUS. Signs of varying degree of severity include UTERINE BLEEDING, uterine MUSCLE HYPERTONIA, and FETAL DISTRESS or FETAL DEATH.
traumatic haemorrhage	Vascular rupture, and the resulting loss of blood, due to physical injury.
premature detachment of placenta	Premature separation of the normally implanted PLACENTA from the UTERUS. Signs of varying degree of severity include UTERINE BLEEDING, uterine MUSCLE HYPERTONIA, and FETAL DISTRESS or FETAL DEATH.
hemorrhage nos	Bleeding or escape of blood from a vessel.
accidental hemorrhage	Premature separation of the normally implanted PLACENTA from the UTERUS. Signs of varying degree of severity include UTERINE BLEEDING, uterine MUSCLE HYPERTONIA, and FETAL DISTRESS or FETAL DEATH.
placenta	A highly vascularized mammalian fetal-maternal organ and major site of transport of oxygen, nutrients, and fetal waste products. It includes a fetal portion (CHORIONIC VILLI) derived from TROPHOBLASTS and a maternal portion (DECIDUA) derived from the uterine ENDOMETRIUM. The placenta produces an array of steroid, protein and peptide hormones (PLACENTAL HORMONES).
ablatio placentae	Premature separation of the normally implanted PLACENTA from the UTERUS. Signs of varying degree of severity include UTERINE BLEEDING, uterine MUSCLE HYPERTONIA, and FETAL DISTRESS or FETAL DEATH.
placentomes	A highly vascularized mammalian fetal-maternal organ and major site of transport of oxygen, nutrients, and fetal waste products. It includes a fetal portion (CHORIONIC VILLI) derived from TROPHOBLASTS and a maternal portion (DECIDUA) derived from the uterine ENDOMETRIUM. The placenta produces an array of steroid, protein and peptide hormones (PLACENTAL HORMONES).
premature separation of placenta	Premature separation of the normally implanted PLACENTA from the UTERUS. Signs of varying degree of severity include UTERINE BLEEDING, uterine MUSCLE HYPERTONIA, and FETAL DISTRESS or FETAL DEATH.
antepartum haemorrhage	A clinical syndrome that is characterized by bleeding during the second or third trimester of pregnancy. Pathologic etiologies attributable to the pregnant state include placenta previa, morbidly adherent placenta, vasa previa, placental abruption, cesarean scar pregnancy, intra-abdominal pregnancy, and uterine rupture.

bleeding	Bleeding or escape of blood from a vessel.
placenta; abruptio	Premature separation of the normally implanted PLACENTA from the UTERUS. Signs of varying degree of severity include UTERINE BLEEDING, uterine MUSCLE HYPERTONIA, and FETAL DISTRESS or FETAL DEATH.
placental	A highly vascularized mammalian fetal-maternal organ and major site of transport of oxygen, nutrients, and fetal waste products. It includes a fetal portion (CHORIONIC VILLI) derived from TROPHOBLASTS and a maternal portion (DECIDUA) derived from the uterine ENDOMETRIUM. The placenta produces an array of steroid, protein and peptide hormones (PLACENTAL HORMONES).

non-neoplastic placenta disorder	A non-neoplastic disorder that arises from the placenta. Representative examples include chorioamnionitis, infarction, and malformations.
placental separation	Premature separation of the normally implanted PLACENTA from the UTERUS. Signs of varying degree of severity include UTERINE BLEEDING, uterine MUSCLE HYPERTONIA, and FETAL DISTRESS or FETAL DEATH.
genitourinary system	All the organs involved in reproduction and the formation and release of URINE. It includes the kidneys, ureters, BLADDER; URETHRA, and the organs of reproduction - ovaries, UTERUS; FALLOPIAN TUBES; VAGINA; and CLITORIS in women and the testes; SEMINAL VESICLES; PROSTATE; seminal ducts; and PENIS in men.
placenta abruptio	Premature separation of the normally implanted PLACENTA from the UTERUS. Signs of varying degree of severity include UTERINE BLEEDING, uterine MUSCLE HYPERTONIA, and FETAL DISTRESS or FETAL DEATH.
female genital tract	female reproductive organs of any species; in humans, external organs include the vulva, bartholin's glands, and clitoris; the internal organs include the vagina, uterus, ovary, and fallopian tubes.
reproductive system	heading term for the organs, glands, tissues, etc that function in producing offspring.
placentae; ablatio	Premature separation of the normally implanted PLACENTA from the UTERUS. Signs of varying degree of severity include UTERINE BLEEDING, uterine MUSCLE HYPERTONIA, and FETAL DISTRESS or FETAL DEATH.
anomaly placenta	An abnormality of the placenta, the organ that connects the developing fetus to the uterine wall to enable nutrient uptake, waste elimination, and gas exchange. [HPO:probinson]
placenta; detachment	Premature separation of the normally implanted PLACENTA from the UTERUS. Signs of varying degree of severity include UTERINE BLEEDING, uterine MUSCLE HYPERTONIA, and FETAL DISTRESS or FETAL DEATH.
antepartum hemorrhage accidental	Premature separation of the normally implanted PLACENTA from the UTERUS. Signs of varying degree of severity include UTERINE BLEEDING, uterine MUSCLE HYPERTONIA, and FETAL DISTRESS or FETAL DEATH.
placental abruption unspecified	Premature separation of the normally implanted PLACENTA from the UTERUS. Signs of varying degree of severity include UTERINE BLEEDING, uterine MUSCLE HYPERTONIA, and FETAL DISTRESS or FETAL DEATH.
bleed	Bleeding or escape of blood from a vessel.
placental disorder	Pathological processes or abnormal functions of the PLACENTA.
haemorrhages	Bleeding or escape of blood from a vessel.
abscess	Accumulation of purulent material in tissues, organs, or circumscribed spaces, usually associated with signs of infection.
cefotetan	A semisynthetic cephamycin antibiotic that is administered intravenously or intramuscularly. The drug is highly resistant to a broad spectrum of beta-lactamases and is active against a wide range of both aerobic and anaerobic gram-positive and gram-negative microorganisms.
cefoxitin	A semisynthetic cephamycin antibiotic resistant to beta-lactamase.
metronidazole	A nitroimidazole used to treat AMEBIASIS; VAGINITIS; TRICHOMONAS INFECTIONS; GIARDIASIS; ANAEROBIC BACTERIA; and TREPONEMAL INFECTIONS.
metronidazole benzoate	The benzoate ester of metronidazole, a synthetic nitroimidazole derivative with antiprotozoal and antibacterial activities.
cefoxitin sodium	The sodium salt form of cefoxitin, a beta-lactam, second-generation cephalosporin antibiotic with bactericidal activity. Cefoxitin sodium binds to and inactivates penicillin-binding proteins (PBP) located on the inner membrane of the bacterial cell wall. PBPs participate in the terminal stages of assembling the bacterial cell wall, and in reshaping the cell wall during cell division. Inactivation of PBPs interferes with the cross-linkage of peptidoglycan chains necessary for bacterial cell wall strength and rigidity. This results in the weakening of the bacterial cell wall and causes cell lysis. Check for "https://www.cancer.gov/about-cancer/treatment/clinical-trials/intervention/C28915" active clinical trials using this agent. ("http://ncit.nci.nih.gov/ncitbrowser/ConceptReport.jsp?dictionary=NCI%20Thesaurus&code=C28915" NCI Thesaurus)
abscess nos	Accumulation of purulent material in tissues, organs, or circumscribed spaces, usually associated with signs of infection.
cefotetan disodium	The disodium salt form of cefotetan and a semi-synthetic, broad-spectrum, beta-lactamase-resistant, second-generation cephalosporin antibiotic with bactericidal activity. Cefotetan disodium causes inhibition of bacterial cell wall synthesis by inactivating penicillin binding proteins (PBPs) thereby interfering with the final transpeptidation step required for cross-linking of peptidoglycan units which are a component of the cell wall. This results in a reduction of cell wall stability and causes cell lysis.
inflammation	A pathological process characterized by injury or destruction of tissues caused by a variety of cytologic and chemical reactions. It is usually manifested by typical signs of pain, heat, redness, swelling, and loss of function.
infection	An illness caused by an infectious agent or its toxins that occurs through the direct or indirect transmission of the infectious agent or its products from an infected individual or via an animal, vector or the inanimate environment to a susceptible animal or human host.
boiled skin	An abscess that develops in the skin and subcutaneous tissues. Causes include folliculitis, furuncle, skin injury, and bacterial infections. Signs and symptoms include the presence of a swollen, tender, and erythematous nodular lesion in the skin associated with fever and chills.
abscess morphology	Accumulation of purulent material in tissues, organs, or circumscribed spaces, usually associated with signs of infection.
unknown eubacteria	One of the three domains of life (the others being Eukarya and ARCHAEA), also called Eubacteria. They are unicellular prokaryotic microorganisms which generally possess rigid cell walls, multiply by cell division, and exhibit three principal forms: round or coccal, rodlike or bacillary, and spiral or spirochetal. Bacteria can be classified by their response to OXYGEN: aerobic, anaerobic, or facultatively anaerobic; by the mode by which they obtain their energy: chemotrophy (via chemical reaction) or PHOTOTROPHY (via light reaction); for chemotrophs by their source of chemical energy: CHEMOLITHOTROPHY (from inorganic compounds) or chemoorganotrophy (from organic compounds); and by their source for CARBON; NITROGEN; etc.; HETEROTROPHY (from organic sources) or AUTOTROPHY (from CARBON DIOXIDE). They can also be classified by whether or not they stain (based on the structure of their CELL WALLS) with CRYSTAL VIOLET dye: gram-negative or gram-positive.
infections and infestations	An illness caused by an infectious agent or its toxins that occurs through the direct or indirect transmission of the infectious agent or its products from an infected individual or via an animal, vector or the inanimate environment to a susceptible animal or human host.
skin/subcutis	A tissue sample that contains the epidermis, dermis, and subcutaneous adipose tissue.
abscesses cutaneous	An abscess that develops in the skin and subcutaneous tissues. Causes include folliculitis, furuncle, skin injury, and bacterial infections. Signs and symptoms include the presence of a swollen, tender, and erythematous nodular lesion in the skin associated with fever and chills.
transmissible disease	An illness caused by an infectious agent or its toxins that occurs through the direct or indirect transmission of the infectious agent or its products from an infected individual or via an animal, vector or the inanimate environment to a susceptible animal or human host.
corticosteroid sensitive aseptic abscess syndrome	A well-defined entity within the group of auto inflammatory disorders, it is a rare disease with 49 cases documented so far. It affects mainly young adults and is characterized by recurrent attacks of fever and deep abscess-like collections, most frequently localized in the abdomen. Aseptic abscesses may be either isolated or associated with an underlying condition such as relapsing polychondritis or inflammatory bowel disease. Antibiotics fail to cure the patients but dramatic improvements are seen with corticosteroids and immunosuppressive drugs.
diseases inflammatory	An infectious or non infectious disorder characterized by signs and symptoms derived from focal or extensive tissue infiltration by acute (e.g., polymorphonuclear) or chronic (e.g., lymphocytic-plasmacytic) inflammatory cells. Representative examples of infectious disorders include viral infections, bacterial infections, and parasitic infections. Representative examples of non-infectious inflammatory disorders include inflammatory bowel disease and inflammatory polyps.
pleurisy; purulent	Suppurative inflammation of the pleural space.
pyothorax	Suppurative inflammation of the pleural space.
abscess; intracranial	An abscess that is located in the intracranial space.
abscesses	Accumulation of purulent material in tissues, organs, or circumscribed spaces, usually associated with signs of infection.
corneal abscess	An abscess of the cornea.
parapharyngeal; abscess	An abscess that develops in the soft tissues of the lateral pharyngeal space.
retro-pharyngeal abscess nos	An accumulation of purulent material in the space between the PHARYNX and the CERVICAL VERTEBRAE. This usually results from SUPPURATION of retropharyngeal LYMPH NODES in patients with UPPER RESPIRATORY TRACT INFECTIONS, perforation of the pharynx, or head and neck injuries.
anorectal abscess	An abscess located at the junction of the anal canal and the rectum. []
abscess; tuberculous	An abscess resulting from infection by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
disorders	A definite pathologic process with a characteristic set of signs and symptoms. It may affect the whole body or any of its parts, and its etiology, pathology, and prognosis may be known or unknown.
inflammatory disease	An infectious or non infectious disorder characterized by signs and symptoms derived from focal or extensive tissue infiltration by acute (e.g., polymorphonuclear) or chronic (e.g., lymphocytic-plasmacytic) inflammatory cells. Representative examples of infectious disorders include viral infections, bacterial infections, and parasitic infections. Representative examples of non-infectious inflammatory disorders include inflammatory bowel disease and inflammatory polyps.
contagious disease	An illness caused by an infectious agent or its toxins that occurs through the direct or indirect transmission of the infectious agent or its products from an infected individual or via an animal, vector or the inanimate environment to a susceptible animal or human host.
brain abscess	A circumscribed collection of purulent exudate in the brain, due to bacterial and other infections. The majority are caused by spread of infected material from a focus of suppuration elsewhere in the body, notably the PARANASAL SINUSES, middle ear (see EAR, MIDDLE); HEART (see also ENDOCARDITIS, BACTERIAL), and LUNG. Penetrating CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA and NEUROSURGICAL PROCEDURES may also be associated with this condition. Clinical manifestations include HEADACHE; SEIZURES; focal neurologic deficits; and alterations of consciousness. (Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, pp712-6)
hepatic abscesses	Solitary or multiple collections of PUS within the liver as a result of infection by bacteria, protozoa, or other agents.
rectal abscess	A collection of pus in the area of the rectum. [HPO:probinson]
spinal extradural abscess	Spinal epidural abscess (SEA) is caused by a suppurative infection in the epidural space. The mass effect ofthe abscess can compress and reduce blood flow to the spinal cord, conus medullaris, or cauda equina. Left untreated, the infection can lead to sensory loss,muscle weakness, visceral dysfunction, sepsis, and even death. Early diagnosis is essential to limit mor-bidity and neurologic injury. The classic triad of fever, axial pain, and neurological deficit occurs in as few as 13 percent of patients, highlighting the diagnosticchallenge associated with SEA. [PMID:24007734, PMID:26540492]
vulval abcess	A circumscribed area of pus or necrotic debris in the vulvar region. [PMID:27617247]
inguinal abscess	A circumscribed area of pus or necrotic debris in the groin (inguinal region). [PMID:23537455]
peritoneal abscess	The presence of an abscess of the peritoneum. [HPO:probinson]
inflammatory disorder abscess	Accumulation of purulent material in tissues, organs, or circumscribed spaces, usually associated with signs of infection.
dental abscess	A pocket of pus located within a region of a tooth. [HPO:probinson]
testicular abscess	A collection of pus within a testicle. Ultrasonographic features include shaggy, irregular walls, intratesticular location, low-level internal echoes, and occasionally, hypervascular margins. [PMID:11598263]
sterile abscess	An abscess not caused by infection with pyogenic bacteria. Operationally, a sterile abscess is inferred if investigations of an abscess fail to reveal evidence of pathogenic organisms. []
microabscess	A very small, tiny abscess.
abscess sterile	An abscess not caused by infection with pyogenic bacteria. Operationally, a sterile abscess is inferred if investigations of an abscess fail to reveal evidence of pathogenic organisms. []
brain--abscess	A circumscribed collection of purulent exudate in the brain, due to bacterial and other infections. The majority are caused by spread of infected material from a focus of suppuration elsewhere in the body, notably the PARANASAL SINUSES, middle ear (see EAR, MIDDLE); HEART (see also ENDOCARDITIS, BACTERIAL), and LUNG. Penetrating CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA and NEUROSURGICAL PROCEDURES may also be associated with this condition. Clinical manifestations include HEADACHE; SEIZURES; focal neurologic deficits; and alterations of consciousness. (Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, pp712-6)
pleural empyema	Suppurative inflammation of the pleural space.
lung empyema	Suppurative inflammation of the pleural space.
abscess of thorax	Suppurative inflammation of the pleural space.
thoracic abscess	Suppurative inflammation of the pleural space.
intracranial abscess	An abscess that is located in the intracranial space.
hepatic abscess	Solitary or multiple collections of PUS within the liver as a result of infection by bacteria, protozoa, or other agents.
liver abscess	Solitary or multiple collections of PUS within the liver as a result of infection by bacteria, protozoa, or other agents.
abscess hepatic	Solitary or multiple collections of PUS within the liver as a result of infection by bacteria, protozoa, or other agents.
abscesses hepatic	Solitary or multiple collections of PUS within the liver as a result of infection by bacteria, protozoa, or other agents.
amebiasis; hepatic	Single or multiple areas of PUS due to infection by any ameboid protozoa (AMEBIASIS). A common form is caused by the ingestion of ENTAMOEBA HISTOLYTICA.
amoebic liver abscess	Single or multiple areas of PUS due to infection by any ameboid protozoa (AMEBIASIS). A common form is caused by the ingestion of ENTAMOEBA HISTOLYTICA.
amebic liver abscess	Single or multiple areas of PUS due to infection by any ameboid protozoa (AMEBIASIS). A common form is caused by the ingestion of ENTAMOEBA HISTOLYTICA.
amoebic liver abscesses	Single or multiple areas of PUS due to infection by any ameboid protozoa (AMEBIASIS). A common form is caused by the ingestion of ENTAMOEBA HISTOLYTICA.
lung abscess	Solitary or multiple collections of PUS within the lung parenchyma as a result of infection by bacteria, protozoa, or other agents.
abscess lung	Solitary or multiple collections of PUS within the lung parenchyma as a result of infection by bacteria, protozoa, or other agents.
lung abscesses	Solitary or multiple collections of PUS within the lung parenchyma as a result of infection by bacteria, protozoa, or other agents.
abscesses pulm	Solitary or multiple collections of PUS within the lung parenchyma as a result of infection by bacteria, protozoa, or other agents.
pelvic abscess	An abscess that is located in the pelvic cavity.
abscesses pelvic	An abscess that is located in the pelvic cavity.
abscess pelvic	An abscess that is located in the pelvic cavity.
perianal abscess	An abscess that develops in the soft tissues surrounding the anal canal. Causes include bacterial and fungal infections, malignancies that involve the perianal region, and Crohn disease.
apical abscess	Acute or chronic inflammation of tissues surrounding the apical portion of a tooth, associated with the collection of pus, resulting from infection following pulp infection through a carious lesion or as a result of an injury causing pulp necrosis. (Dorland, 27th ed)
tooth root periapical abscess	Acute or chronic inflammation of tissues surrounding the apical portion of a tooth, associated with the collection of pus, resulting from infection following pulp infection through a carious lesion or as a result of an injury causing pulp necrosis. (Dorland, 27th ed)
periodontal abscess	Localized circumscribed purulent area of inflammation in the periodontal tissue. It is a derivative of marginal periodontitis and commonly associated with suprabony and infrabony pockets and interradicular involvements, in contrast to periapical abscess which is attributable to pulp necrosis.
lateral alveolar abscess	Localized circumscribed purulent area of inflammation in the periodontal tissue. It is a derivative of marginal periodontitis and commonly associated with suprabony and infrabony pockets and interradicular involvements, in contrast to periapical abscess which is attributable to pulp necrosis.
parodontal abscess	Localized circumscribed purulent area of inflammation in the periodontal tissue. It is a derivative of marginal periodontitis and commonly associated with suprabony and infrabony pockets and interradicular involvements, in contrast to periapical abscess which is attributable to pulp necrosis.
quinsy	An accumulation of purulent material in the area between the PALATINE TONSIL and its capsule.
subdural abscess	An intracranial or rarely intraspinal suppurative process invading the space between the inner surface of the DURA MATER and the outer surface of the ARACHNOID.
subdural empyema	An intracranial or rarely intraspinal suppurative process invading the space between the inner surface of the DURA MATER and the outer surface of the ARACHNOID.
subphrenic abscess	Accumulation of purulent EXUDATES beneath the DIAPHRAGM, also known as upper abdominal abscess. It is usually associated with PERITONITIS or postoperative infections.
tubo-ovarian abscess	An abscess involving the distal fallopian tube and ovary. It is caused by pelvic inflammatory disease or other infections.
tuboovarian abscess	An abscess involving the distal fallopian tube and ovary. It is caused by pelvic inflammatory disease or other infections.
psoas abscess	Abscess of the PSOAS MUSCLES resulting usually from disease of the lumbar vertebrae, with the pus descending into the muscle sheath. The infection is most commonly tuberculous or staphylococcal.
psoas muscle abscess	Abscess of the PSOAS MUSCLES resulting usually from disease of the lumbar vertebrae, with the pus descending into the muscle sheath. The infection is most commonly tuberculous or staphylococcal.
iliopsoas abscess	Abscess of the PSOAS MUSCLES resulting usually from disease of the lumbar vertebrae, with the pus descending into the muscle sheath. The infection is most commonly tuberculous or staphylococcal.
iliopsoas abscesses	Abscess of the PSOAS MUSCLES resulting usually from disease of the lumbar vertebrae, with the pus descending into the muscle sheath. The infection is most commonly tuberculous or staphylococcal.
boils rectal	A collection of pus in the area of the rectum. [HPO:probinson]
cutaneous abscess	An abscess that develops in the skin and subcutaneous tissues. Causes include folliculitis, furuncle, skin injury, and bacterial infections. Signs and symptoms include the presence of a swollen, tender, and erythematous nodular lesion in the skin associated with fever and chills.
skin abscess	An abscess that develops in the skin and subcutaneous tissues. Causes include folliculitis, furuncle, skin injury, and bacterial infections. Signs and symptoms include the presence of a swollen, tender, and erythematous nodular lesion in the skin associated with fever and chills.
renal abscess	An abscess that is located within the renal parenchyma.
parapharyngeal abscess	An abscess that develops in the soft tissues of the lateral pharyngeal space.
abscess of parapharyngeal space	An abscess that develops in the soft tissues of the lateral pharyngeal space.
retropharyngeal abscess	An accumulation of purulent material in the space between the PHARYNX and the CERVICAL VERTEBRAE. This usually results from SUPPURATION of retropharyngeal LYMPH NODES in patients with UPPER RESPIRATORY TRACT INFECTIONS, perforation of the pharynx, or head and neck injuries.
renal and perinephric abscess	An abscess that is located both in the kidney and across the renal capsule into the perinephric space.
renal/perirenal abscess	An abscess that is located both in the kidney and across the renal capsule into the perinephric space.
renal/perinephric abscess	An abscess that is located both in the kidney and across the renal capsule into the perinephric space.
retroperitoneal abscess	An abscess that is located in the abdominal cavity posterior to the peritoneum.
perinephric abscess	An abscess that is located outside the renal capsule, but which is within Gerota's space.
perirenal abscess	An abscess that is located outside the renal capsule, but which is within Gerota's space.
pancreatic abscess	A circumscribed area of pus or necrotic debris in the parenchyma of the pancreas. []
spinal epidural abscess	Spinal epidural abscess (SEA) is caused by a suppurative infection in the epidural space. The mass effect ofthe abscess can compress and reduce blood flow to the spinal cord, conus medullaris, or cauda equina. Left untreated, the infection can lead to sensory loss,muscle weakness, visceral dysfunction, sepsis, and even death. Early diagnosis is essential to limit mor-bidity and neurologic injury. The classic triad of fever, axial pain, and neurological deficit occurs in as few as 13 percent of patients, highlighting the diagnosticchallenge associated with SEA. [PMID:24007734, PMID:26540492]
abdominal abscess	An abscess located in the abdominal cavity, i.e., the cavity between the diaphragm above and the pelvis below. (From Dorland, 27th ed)
vulval abscess	A circumscribed area of pus or necrotic debris in the vulvar region. [PMID:27617247]
abscess of vulva	A circumscribed area of pus or necrotic debris in the vulvar region. [PMID:27617247]
vulvar abscess	A circumscribed area of pus or necrotic debris in the vulvar region. [PMID:27617247]
abscess; vulva	A circumscribed area of pus or necrotic debris in the vulvar region. [PMID:27617247]
abscess groin	A circumscribed area of pus or necrotic debris in the groin (inguinal region). [PMID:23537455]
groin abscess	A circumscribed area of pus or necrotic debris in the groin (inguinal region). [PMID:23537455]
abscess of groin	A circumscribed area of pus or necrotic debris in the groin (inguinal region). [PMID:23537455]
axillary abscess	A collection of pus that has formed in the axilla.
periapical abscess with sinus	Localized collection of pus in the tissues that enclose the root of a tooth and is associated with the presence of a sinus tract.
mesenteric abscess	An abscess that is located in any part of the tissue composing the mesentery, and that generally arises from an infection in an adjacent area of the intestine.
pyogenic hepatic abscesses	Varbildning i leverparenkymet till följd av bakterieinfektion. Abscessen kan vara orsakad av en rad olika bakterier, lokal eller spridd från infektioner i andra organ, som t ex blindtarmsinflammation, gallblåseinflammation, bukhinneinflammation, eller efter levertransplantation.
pyogenic liver abscess	Varbildning i leverparenkymet till följd av bakterieinfektion. Abscessen kan vara orsakad av en rad olika bakterier, lokal eller spridd från infektioner i andra organ, som t ex blindtarmsinflammation, gallblåseinflammation, bukhinneinflammation, eller efter levertransplantation.
epidural abscess	Circumscribed collections of suppurative material occurring in the spinal or intracranial EPIDURAL SPACE. The majority of epidural abscesses occur in the spinal canal and are associated with OSTEOMYELITIS of a vertebral body; ANALGESIA, EPIDURAL; and other conditions. Clinical manifestations include local and radicular pain, weakness, sensory loss, URINARY INCONTINENCE, and FECAL INCONTINENCE. Cranial epidural abscesses are usually associated with OSTEOMYELITIS of a cranial bone, SINUSITIS, or OTITIS MEDIA. (From Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, p710 and pp1240-1; J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1998 Aug;65(2):209-12)
pituitary abscess	An inflammatory or infectious process in the pituitary gland characterized by a circumscribed, walled collection of purulent material.
abscessed lymph nodes	An abscess that develops in a lymph node and the surrounding tissues as a result of an infectious process. The affected lymph node is palpable and tender.
splenic abscess	A circumscribed area of pus or necrotic debris in the parenchyma of the spleen. [PMID:21319348]
cerebral cysticercosis	Infection of the brain, spinal cord, or perimeningeal structures with the larval forms of the genus TAENIA (primarily T. solium in humans). Lesions formed by the organism are referred to as cysticerci. The infection may be subacute or chronic, and the severity of symptoms depends on the severity of the host immune response and the location and number of lesions. SEIZURES represent the most common clinical manifestation although focal neurologic deficits may occur. (From Joynt, Clinical Neurology, 1998, Ch27, pp46-50)
abscess of thyroid	A rare disorder characterized by the development of an abscess in the thyroid gland. It usually follows an upper respiratory tract, pharyngeal, or middle ear infection. It is usually caused by Staphylococcus or Streptococcus infection. It presents with fever, pain, and neck mass.
teeth; abscess	A pocket of pus located within a region of a tooth. [HPO:probinson]
testis; abscess	A collection of pus within a testicle. Ultrasonographic features include shaggy, irregular walls, intratesticular location, low-level internal echoes, and occasionally, hypervascular margins. [PMID:11598263]
abscess testis	A collection of pus within a testicle. Ultrasonographic features include shaggy, irregular walls, intratesticular location, low-level internal echoes, and occasionally, hypervascular margins. [PMID:11598263]
intratesticular abscess	A collection of pus within a testicle. Ultrasonographic features include shaggy, irregular walls, intratesticular location, low-level internal echoes, and occasionally, hypervascular margins. [PMID:11598263]
labial abscess	A circumscribed area of pus or necrotic debris in the labia. [PMID:7598776]
abscess of the labia	A circumscribed area of pus or necrotic debris in the labia. [PMID:7598776]
abscess of labia	A circumscribed area of pus or necrotic debris in the labia. [PMID:7598776]
tuberculous abscess	An abscess resulting from infection by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.
parenchymal intracranial abscess	A bacterial, fungal, or parasitic abscess that develops in the cerebral hemispheres. Causes include skull trauma, middle ear infection, congenital heart disease, and frontal and ethmoid sinus infection.
cerebral abscess	A bacterial, fungal, or parasitic abscess that develops in the cerebral hemispheres. Causes include skull trauma, middle ear infection, congenital heart disease, and frontal and ethmoid sinus infection.
pilonidal cyst with abscess	A hair-containing cyst or sinus usually in the coccygeal region. [HPO:probinson]
suppurative pleurisy	Suppurative inflammation of the pleural space.
abscess; anorectal	An abscess located at the junction of the anal canal and the rectum. []
abscess; extradural	Circumscribed collections of suppurative material occurring in the spinal or intracranial EPIDURAL SPACE. The majority of epidural abscesses occur in the spinal canal and are associated with OSTEOMYELITIS of a vertebral body; ANALGESIA, EPIDURAL; and other conditions. Clinical manifestations include local and radicular pain, weakness, sensory loss, URINARY INCONTINENCE, and FECAL INCONTINENCE. Cranial epidural abscesses are usually associated with OSTEOMYELITIS of a cranial bone, SINUSITIS, or OTITIS MEDIA. (From Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, p710 and pp1240-1; J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 1998 Aug;65(2):209-12)
lymph node abscessed	An abscess that develops in a lymph node and the surrounding tissues as a result of an infectious process. The affected lymph node is palpable and tender.
diseases	A definite pathologic process with a characteristic set of signs and symptoms. It may affect the whole body or any of its parts, and its etiology, pathology, and prognosis may be known or unknown.
communicable disease	An illness caused by an infectious agent or its toxins that occurs through the direct or indirect transmission of the infectious agent or its products from an infected individual or via an animal, vector or the inanimate environment to a susceptible animal or human host.
infectious agent	Any organism, such as a virus, parasite, or bacterium, that is capable of invading body tissues and multiplying.
abscess; brain	A circumscribed collection of purulent exudate in the brain, due to bacterial and other infections. The majority are caused by spread of infected material from a focus of suppuration elsewhere in the body, notably the PARANASAL SINUSES, middle ear (see EAR, MIDDLE); HEART (see also ENDOCARDITIS, BACTERIAL), and LUNG. Penetrating CRANIOCEREBRAL TRAUMA and NEUROSURGICAL PROCEDURES may also be associated with this condition. Clinical manifestations include HEADACHE; SEIZURES; focal neurologic deficits; and alterations of consciousness. (Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, pp712-6)
gallbladder empyema	Přítomnost hnisu ve žlučníku.
empyema chest	Suppurative inflammation of the pleural space.
abscess of pleural cavity	Suppurative inflammation of the pleural space.
intracranial abscess nos	An abscess that is located in the intracranial space.
intracranial; abscess	An abscess that is located in the intracranial space.
abscess of liver	Solitary or multiple collections of PUS within the liver as a result of infection by bacteria, protozoa, or other agents.
liver--abscess	Solitary or multiple collections of PUS within the liver as a result of infection by bacteria, protozoa, or other agents.
amoebic hepatic abscesses	Single or multiple areas of PUS due to infection by any ameboid protozoa (AMEBIASIS). A common form is caused by the ingestion of ENTAMOEBA HISTOLYTICA.
abscess of lung	Solitary or multiple collections of PUS within the lung parenchyma as a result of infection by bacteria, protozoa, or other agents.
abscess; lung	Solitary or multiple collections of PUS within the lung parenchyma as a result of infection by bacteria, protozoa, or other agents.
abscess perianal	An abscess that develops in the soft tissues surrounding the anal canal. Causes include bacterial and fungal infections, malignancies that involve the perianal region, and Crohn disease.

crypt abscess	Accumulation of polymorphonuclear neutrophils in the mucosal crypts of the colon. It occurs in ulcerative colitis.

perihepatic abscess	An abscess that is located in the anatomical space surrounding the liver, but which is outside of the liver capsule itself.
prevertebral abscess	An abscess that develops in the tissues within the prevertebral fascia.
send-nonneo	The terminology that includes concepts relevant to non-neoplastic microscopic findings.
pediatric infectious disease terminology	Terminology developed by a collaborative effort of the National Cancer Institute's Enterprise Vocabulary Services, the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development, and an international group of clinicians and informaticists to support the reporting of events in the pediatric population with issues pertaining to infectious diseases.
abscisic acid	Abscission-accelerating plant growth substance isolated from young cotton fruit, leaves of sycamore, birch, and other plants, and from potatoes, lemons, avocados, and other fruits.
phytohormone	Any of the hormones produced naturally in plants and active in controlling growth and other functions. There are three primary classes: auxins, cytokinins, and gibberellins.
plant growth reg	Any of the hormones produced naturally in plants and active in controlling growth and other functions. There are three primary classes: auxins, cytokinins, and gibberellins.
phytohormones	Any of the hormones produced naturally in plants and active in controlling growth and other functions. There are three primary classes: auxins, cytokinins, and gibberellins.
plant hormone	Any of the hormones produced naturally in plants and active in controlling growth and other functions. There are three primary classes: auxins, cytokinins, and gibberellins.
abscisin	Abscission-accelerating plant growth substance isolated from young cotton fruit, leaves of sycamore, birch, and other plants, and from potatoes, lemons, avocados, and other fruits.
plant growth regulators	Any of the hormones produced naturally in plants and active in controlling growth and other functions. There are three primary classes: auxins, cytokinins, and gibberellins.
growth reg plant	Any of the hormones produced naturally in plants and active in controlling growth and other functions. There are three primary classes: auxins, cytokinins, and gibberellins.
aplasia	A congenital abnormality resulting in the absence of an anatomical structure.
cdisc terminology	The terminology that includes terms relevant to the Clinical Data Interchange Standards Consortium.
corpus callosum agenesis	Birth defect that results in a partial or complete absence of the CORPUS CALLOSUM. It may be isolated or a part of a syndrome (e.g., AICARDI'S SYNDROME; ACROCALLOSAL SYNDROME; ANDERMANN SYNDROME; and HOLOPROSENCEPHALY). Clinical manifestations include neuromotor skill impairment and INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY of variable severity.
athelia	Congenital failure to develop, and absence of, the nipple. []
syndrome potter	A rare, lethal congenital malformation characterized by bilateral renal agenesis and the absence or decreased volume of amniotic fluid (oligohydramnios). The presence of oligohydramnios gives rise to congenital anomalies that include hypoplastic lungs, lower extremities abnormalities, and characteristic facial features (low-set ears, widely separated eyes, nose flattening, and receding chin). Newborn infants usually die of respiratory failure.
agenesis of diaphragm	Congenital lack, i.e., aplasia of the diaphragm. [HPO:probinson]
absence of diaphragm	Congenital lack, i.e., aplasia of the diaphragm. [HPO:probinson]
femoral aplasia	Failure of the femur to develop. [HPO:probinson]
proximal phocomelia of lower limb	Failure of the femur to develop. [HPO:probinson]
nose agenesia	Complete absence of all nasal structures. [HPO:probinson]
pulmonary agenesis	An uncommon congenital abnormality characterized by either lethal complete absence of the lungs or varying degrees of underdevelopment of the lung parenchyma. It may be associated with other congenital abnormalities.
apulmonism	An uncommon congenital abnormality characterized by either lethal complete absence of the lungs or varying degrees of underdevelopment of the lung parenchyma. It may be associated with other congenital abnormalities.
congenital absence of pulmonary artery	A congenital defect with aplasia (absence) of one of the right or left pulmonary artery. [HPO:probinson, PMID:17192541]
agenesis of gallbladder	A developmental defect in which the gallbladder fails to form. [DDD:hfirth]
hepatic agenesis	Absence of the liver owing to a failure of the liver to develop. [HPO:probinson]
agenesis; liver	Absence of the liver owing to a failure of the liver to develop. [HPO:probinson]
congenital absence of uterus	A congenital abnormality characterized by the complete absence of the uterus.
complete dental agenesis	Congenital absence of the teeth; it may involve all (total anodontia) or only some of the teeth (partial anodontia, hypodontia), and both the deciduous and the permanent dentition, or only teeth of the permanent dentition. (Dorland, 27th ed)
teeth absent	Congenital absence of the teeth; it may involve all (total anodontia) or only some of the teeth (partial anodontia, hypodontia), and both the deciduous and the permanent dentition, or only teeth of the permanent dentition. (Dorland, 27th ed)
agenesis of the lower vagina	A failure to develop of the lower part of the vagina. [HPO:probinson]
agenesis of cervical vertebra	Agenesis of one or more vertebrae of the cervical vertebral column. [HPO:probinson]
absent kidney	A congenital abnormality characterized by the absence of one or both kidneys.
absent spleen	Congenital or functional absence of spleen
mandibular aplasia	Absence of the mandible. [HPO:curators]
agenesis of maxilla	A congenital defect characterized by absence of the Maxilla. [HPO:probinson]
failure of development of maxilla	A congenital defect characterized by absence of the Maxilla. [HPO:probinson]
absent thymus	Absence of the thymus. This feature may be appreciated by the lack of a thymic shadow upon radiographic examination. [HPO:probinson]
athymia	Absence of the thymus. This feature may be appreciated by the lack of a thymic shadow upon radiographic examination. [HPO:probinson]
tracheal absence	Congenital absence of the trachea.
acrorenoocular syndromes	A syndrome consisting of Duane's syndrome, radial ray anomaly, and frequently, HEARING LOSS, SENSORINEURAL.
sommer hines syndrome	A rare genetic congenital limb malformation disorder with characteristics of the presence of a single digit on all four extremities. The malformation is typically isolated however, aplastic and hypoplastic defects in the remaining skeletal parts of hands and feet have been reported. There have been no further descriptions in the literature since 1992.
tetra-amelia	A genetic syndrome characterized by the absence of all four limbs.
autosomal recessive tetra-amelia	A genetic syndrome characterized by the absence of all four limbs.
zimmer taub sova syndrome	An extremely rare mostly lethal congenital disorder with characteristics of absence of all four limbs and frequent associated major malformations involving the head, face, eyes, skeleton, heart, lungs, anus, urogenital, and central nervous systems. The syndrome has been described in fewer than 20 patients mainly of Middle Eastern descent.
tetraamelia with multiple malformation syndrome	An extremely rare mostly lethal congenital disorder with characteristics of absence of all four limbs and frequent associated major malformations involving the head, face, eyes, skeleton, heart, lungs, anus, urogenital, and central nervous systems. The syndrome has been described in fewer than 20 patients mainly of Middle Eastern descent.
zimmer phocomelia	An extremely rare mostly lethal congenital disorder with characteristics of absence of all four limbs and frequent associated major malformations involving the head, face, eyes, skeleton, heart, lungs, anus, urogenital, and central nervous systems. The syndrome has been described in fewer than 20 patients mainly of Middle Eastern descent.
bilateral pulmonary agenesis	Bilateral lack of development of the lungs. [HPO:probinson]
agenesis of bilateral lungs	Bilateral lack of development of the lungs. [HPO:probinson]
lowry syndrome	An extremely rare genetic disease reported in only two brothers to date with the combination of craniosynostosis (involving both coronal sutures), congenital absence of the fibula, cryptorchidism, and bilateral simian creases. Intelligence is normal. There have been no further reports in the literature since 1972.
sommer rathbun battles syndrome	An extremely rare syndrome reported in two siblings of non-consanguineous parents with the association of ocular abnormalities (partial aniridia, congenital glaucoma, telecanthus) with frontal bossing, hypertelorism, unilateral renal agenesis and mild psychomotor delay. There have been no further descriptions in the literature since 1974.
isolated arhinencephaly	A rare non-syndromic central nervous system malformation defined by the agenesis of the olfactory bulbs and tracts and with characteristics of complete congenital anosmia.
enamel ageneses	Una forma de amelogénesis imperfecta caracterizada por formación incompleta del esmalte dental y transmitida como rasgo autosómico dominante o ligado al cromosoma X.
anophthalmos nos	Congenital absence of the eye or eyes.
agenesis of vertebra	A developmental defect characterized by agenesis of one or more vertebral bodies. [PMID:26167231]
absent vertebrae	A developmental defect characterized by agenesis of one or more vertebral bodies. [PMID:26167231]
corpus callosum dysgeneses	Birth defect that results in a partial or complete absence of the CORPUS CALLOSUM. It may be isolated or a part of a syndrome (e.g., AICARDI'S SYNDROME; ACROCALLOSAL SYNDROME; ANDERMANN SYNDROME; and HOLOPROSENCEPHALY). Clinical manifestations include neuromotor skill impairment and INTELLECTUAL DISABILITY of variable severity.
syndrome; potter	A rare, lethal congenital malformation characterized by bilateral renal agenesis and the absence or decreased volume of amniotic fluid (oligohydramnios). The presence of oligohydramnios gives rise to congenital anomalies that include hypoplastic lungs, lower extremities abnormalities, and characteristic facial features (low-set ears, widely separated eyes, nose flattening, and receding chin). Newborn infants usually die of respiratory failure.
diaphragm aplasia	Congenital lack, i.e., aplasia of the diaphragm. [HPO:probinson]
acheiria	The total absence of the hand, with no bony elements distal to the radius or ulna. [PMID:19125433]
agenesis; hand	The total absence of the hand, with no bony elements distal to the radius or ulna. [PMID:19125433]
agenesis of foot	The total absence of the foot, with no bony elements distal to the tibia or fibula. [PMID:19125433]
absent femur	Failure of the femur to develop. [HPO:probinson]
aplasia of lung	An uncommon congenital abnormality characterized by either lethal complete absence of the lungs or varying degrees of underdevelopment of the lung parenchyma. It may be associated with other congenital abnormalities.
congenital absence of lung	An uncommon congenital abnormality characterized by either lethal complete absence of the lungs or varying degrees of underdevelopment of the lung parenchyma. It may be associated with other congenital abnormalities.
pulmonary artery agenesis	A congenital defect with aplasia (absence) of one of the right or left pulmonary artery. [HPO:probinson, PMID:17192541]
atresia; gallbladder	A developmental defect in which the gallbladder fails to form. [DDD:hfirth]
congenital absence of liver	Absence of the liver owing to a failure of the liver to develop. [HPO:probinson]
aplasia of uterus	A congenital abnormality characterized by the complete absence of the uterus.
ablepharon - absent eyelids	Absent eyelids. [PMID:19125427]
congenital edentia	Congenital absence of the teeth; it may involve all (total anodontia) or only some of the teeth (partial anodontia, hypodontia), and both the deciduous and the permanent dentition, or only teeth of the permanent dentition. (Dorland, 27th ed)
partial agenesis of corpus callosum	A partial failure of the development of the corpus callosum. [HPO:curators]
aplasia of the lower vagina	A failure to develop of the lower part of the vagina. [HPO:probinson]
congenital absence of spleen	Congenital or functional absence of spleen
splenic agenesis	Congenital or functional absence of spleen
agenesis of thymus	Absence of the thymus. This feature may be appreciated by the lack of a thymic shadow upon radiographic examination. [HPO:probinson]
congenital absence of auricle	Complete absence of any auricular structures. [HPO:probinson, PMID:19125421]
agenesis; trachea	Congenital absence of the trachea.
agenesis of parathyroid gland	Aplasia of the parathyroid gland. [HPO:probinson]
vici syndrome	A very rare and severe congenital multisystem disorder with the principal features of agenesis of the corpus callosum, cataracts, oculocutaneous hypopigmentation, cardiomyopathy and combined immunodeficiency. Usually diagnosed in the first years of life. The phenotype is variable but the principal diagnostic features are almost always present at onset or evolve over time. Caused by mutations in the EPG5 gene (18q12.3) which encodes an important autophagy regulator, ectopic P-granules autophagy protein 5 (epg5). Formation of autolysosomes is specifically disturbed by an epg5 deficiency.
holzgreve syndrome	An extremely rare lethal multiple congenital anomalies/dysmorphic syndrome with characteristics of renal agenesis with Potter sequence, cleft lip/palate, oral synechiae, cardiac defects, and skeletal abnormalities including postaxial polydactyly. Intestinal nonfixation and intrauterine growth restriction are also associated. There have been no further descriptions in the literature since 1988.
tetraamelia	A genetic syndrome characterized by the absence of all four limbs.
tetra-amelia with multiple malformation syndrome	An extremely rare mostly lethal congenital disorder with characteristics of absence of all four limbs and frequent associated major malformations involving the head, face, eyes, skeleton, heart, lungs, anus, urogenital, and central nervous systems. The syndrome has been described in fewer than 20 patients mainly of Middle Eastern descent.
x-linked intellectual disability kroes type	A rare genetic syndrome with cerebellar malformation as a major feature. Characteristics included cerebellar vermis hypo or aplasia, ventriculomegaly, agenesis of corpus callosum and abnormalities of the brainstem and cerebral cortex in association with ocular coloboma. Clinically, patients show hydrocephalus at birth, neonatal hypotonia with abnormal breathing pattern, and ocular abnormalities with impaired vision, severe psychomotor delay, and seizures.
anophthalmos of bilateral eyes	A rare congenital abnormality characterized by the complete absence of ocular tissue in both orbits.
agenesis of internal carotid artery	A developmental defect that may be asymptomatic or lead to cerebrovascular lesions. It is a rare malformation, with only around hundred cases reported in the literature. When symptoms are present, they are caused by cerebrovascular insufficiency, compression of the brain by vessels that dilate to compensate for the absence of the internal carotid artery, or the presence of an aneurysm. Associated intracranial aneurysms occur in 25 to 35% of patients.
absenteeism	Chronic absence from work or other duty.
truancy	Student's deliberate, often chronic absence from school without an accepted medical or other justifiable reason.
behavior	The observable response of a man or animal to a situation.
absidia species	A genus of zygomycetous fungi, family Mucoraceae, order MUCORALES, which sometimes causes infection in humans.
mucoromycotina	A taxonomic grouping of saprotrophic fungi in the Mucoromycotina subphylum.
absidia	A genus of zygomycetous fungi, family Mucoraceae, order MUCORALES, which sometimes causes infection in humans.
cdisc sdtm microorganism terminology	Microorganisms, bacteria, fungi and other organisms.
mucorales	An order of zygomycetous fungi, usually saprophytic, causing damage to food in storage, but which may cause respiratory infection or MUCORMYCOSIS in persons suffering from other debilitating diseases.
photon absorptiometry	A noninvasive method for assessing BODY COMPOSITION. It is based on the differential absorption of X-RAYS (or GAMMA RAYS) by different tissues such as bone, fat and other soft tissues. The source of (X-ray or gamma-ray) photon beam is generated either from radioisotopes such as GADOLINIUM 153, IODINE 125, or Americanium 241 which emit GAMMA RAYS in the appropriate range; or from an X-ray tube which produces X-RAYS in the desired range. It is primarily used for quantitating BONE MINERAL CONTENT, especially for the diagnosis of OSTEOPOROSIS, and also in measuring BONE MINERALIZATION.
dual x ray absorptiometry	An imaging test that measures bone density (the amount of bone mineral contained in a certain volume of bone) by passing x-rays with two different energy levels through the bone. It is used to diagnose osteoporosis (decrease in bone mass and density).
dpx absorptiometry	An imaging test that measures bone density (the amount of bone mineral contained in a certain volume of bone) by passing x-rays with two different energy levels through the bone. It is used to diagnose osteoporosis (decrease in bone mass and density).
abstracting	The process of creating a summary of the main points of an article, argument, or theory.
action	A thing done.
indexing abstracting	Works about activities performed to identify concepts and aspects of published information and research reports.
indexing	Analytisk emneordsbeskrivelse av arbeider innen et bestemt vitenskapsområde.
indexing and abstracting	Works about activities performed to identify concepts and aspects of published information and research reports.
abstracts	A written summary of the important points of a scientific article.
acacia	A plant genus of the family FABACEAE. The gums and tanning agents obtained from Acacia are called GUM ARABIC. The common name catechu is more often used for Areca catechu (ARECA).
conifer	Podskupina rostlin s vyvinutými cévními svazky. Příkladem jsou kapraďorosty a semenné rostliny.
family leguminosae	large family of angiosperm plants characterized by pods.
univ med centers	Medical complexes consisting of medical school, hospitals, clinics, libraries, administrative facilities, etc.
environment: hospital	Physical, organizational, or psychological characteristics of a hospital, and their potential impact on hospital staff and patients.

product containing ketoconazole	Broad spectrum antifungal agent used for long periods at high doses, especially in immunosuppressed patients.
corneal infection	A disorder characterized by an infectious process involving the cornea.
cornea	The transparent anterior portion of the fibrous coat of the eye consisting of five layers: stratified squamous CORNEAL EPITHELIUM; BOWMAN MEMBRANE; CORNEAL STROMA; DESCEMET MEMBRANE; and mesenchymal CORNEAL ENDOTHELIUM. It serves as the first refracting medium of the eye. It is structurally continuous with the SCLERA, avascular, receiving its nourishment by permeation through spaces between the lamellae, and is innervated by the ophthalmic division of the TRIGEMINAL NERVE via the ciliary nerves and those of the surrounding conjunctiva which together form plexuses. (Cline et al., Dictionary of Visual Science, 4th ed)
infectious diseases	An illness caused by an infectious agent or its toxins that occurs through the direct or indirect transmission of the infectious agent or its products from an infected individual or via an animal, vector or the inanimate environment to a susceptible animal or human host.
keratitis	Inflammation of the cornea.
acanthamoeba keratitides	Infection of the cornea by an ameboid protozoan which may cause corneal ulceration leading to blindness.
parasitic ocular infection	Mild to severe infections of the eye and its adjacent structures (adnexa) by adult or larval protozoan or metazoan parasites.
disease caused by parasite	Infections or infestations with PARASITES. They are often contracted through contact with an intermediate vector, but may occur as the result of direct exposure.
cornea infection	A disorder characterized by an infectious process involving the cornea.
infectious keratitis	Inflammation of the cornea secondary to an infectious process.

inflammations	A pathological process characterized by injury or destruction of tissues caused by a variety of cytologic and chemical reactions. It is usually manifested by typical signs of pain, heat, redness, swelling, and loss of function.
